solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We know we only have 10 customers at worst. We also know we have at most 50 unique items in our set up. We can backtrack on the customers and on the items, and can limit ourselves to only as many items as we have customers if we go in greatest reversed order of items present. This lets us limit ourselves appropriately to a space at worst of 10^10. We can allow ourselves to stop early by utilizing a backtracking string to target the current items and current customers as a key, thus letting us memoize results and reduce computational time altogether. 

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Find your number of items, your number of customers, and then check to make sure you at least have enough items to match customers before any combinations. 

Then, get the frequency of your items. 
Turn nums into the sorted form of the frequencies (not the items, the frequencies) in reverse order for as many as you have customers. This lets you focus on a subset of size 10^10 at worst. 

Sort your quantities in reverse. 

If your sum of item frequencies is less than the sum of your quantity, you can also return False already. 

Otherwise, set up a memo 

During the backtracking phase, pass in the current items, customer index, and current customer statuses 
- Build a backtrack key using the items sorted | customer status sorted as a string 
- If your customer index is past the total number number of customers, set memo at backtrack key to true and return true 
- If you have the backtrack key in the memo, return what you found already and skip the preprocess. This is the reason for the sorting as it combines similar set ups with different location strings. 
- otherwise, get the current amount as quantity at customer index 
- set your current item index to 0 
- while your current item index is in range of your current items length 
    - if the item here is not big enough -> move forward by 1 until it is 
    - otherwise 
        - if the current item index is greater than 0 and we have matching items here 
            - go until the last version of these if you can 
            - if you end up out of range, break 
            - otherwise if you end up at a bad spot, move forward one and continue 
        - otherwise try to use the current item to satisfy the current customer, updating in both lists appropriately 
        - make a temp key of doing so 
        - if you have seen this temp key and it doesn't work 
            - unset what you did and move forward one and continue 
        - if you saw it and it did work 
            - set memo for the backtrack key and return True 
        - otherwise, go check it out
            - then update the memo
            - if it was true, update memo for backtrack key and return 
            - otherwise, undo the look, move forward and continue 
- if you never got a success in the loop, update the memo here and return False 

To solve, kick off backtrack with nums, 0, quantity           

# Complexity
- Time complexity : O (Sum m! / (i!(m-i)!) for i in range 1, m-1, where m is number of customers)
    - O(10^10) at worst since we do 10^10 considerations in our backtracking is the naive amount 
    - However, we can limit down since our sort for the backtrack keys worked (never caused an error) to O(3629822) operations, since we now know that we are dealing with combinatory states where no repeats are allowed and order doesn't matter (otherwise, the backtrack keys would have caused a problem). Due to this, we get the time complexity of combinations with no repeats instead of permutations with repeats for the backtrack process.   
    - This puts our overall time complexity in the form of O(Sum m!/(i!(m-i)!) for i in range 1, m-1), where m is the number of customers according to the problem statement. For comparison sakes, this is about 2750 times faster than O(10^10)

- Space complexity : Due to backtracking nature, we match our space complexity unfortunately, but due handidly beat the space in the other case due to our size reduction. If someone is interested, this can potentially be done in bottom up form and save us the massive amounts of space with the time savings. 

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool :
        '''
            at most 50 unique values in the array 
            customer quantities -> no more than 10 customers -> m 
                                -> each customer can order between 1 and 10^5, the number of items range as well 
            nums -> amount of items 
            want to distribute nums so that 
                each customer gets exactly customer_i items (so if there are not exactly i items not gonna work)
                the integers that compose the ith customer order are all equal and sum to customer i items 
                every customer can be satisfied 
        
        '''
        # get number of items and number of customers 
        number_of_items = len(nums)
        number_of_customers = len(quantity) 
        # before doing frequency work, if you do not have enough items, you'll never satisfy everyone 
        if number_of_items < number_of_customers : 
            return False 
        # find out your frequency of your items 
        frequency_of_items = collections.Counter(nums)
        # and limit yourself to the best for your customers 
        nums = sorted(frequency_of_items.values(), reverse=True)[:number_of_customers]
        quantity.sort(reverse = True)
        # if you still can't satisfy everyone, don't try and return False 
        if sum(nums) < sum(quantity) : 
            return False 
        # set up a memo to track your progress 
        self.memo = dict() 

        def backtrack(current_items, customer_index, current_customers) :
            # set up a backtrack key where you use the sorted form of each to capture as many possible alternate substates as you can 
            backtrack_key = "".join([str(c_it) for c_it in sorted(current_items)]) + "-" + "".join([str(c_c) for c_c in sorted(current_customers)]) 
            # if you reached the end, mark it and return True. Otherwise, if you've seen this, return what you already found! 
            if customer_index == number_of_customers : 
                self.memo[backtrack_key] = True
                return True 
            elif backtrack_key in self.memo : 
                return self.memo[backtrack_key]

            # figure out how much you have 
            current_amount = quantity[customer_index]

            # consider all your items 
            c_i = 0 
            while c_i < len(current_items) :
                # if we have an item that is gte here  
                if current_items[c_i] >= current_amount :
                    # if we are past 0 and have a matching situation  
                    if c_i > 0 and current_items[c_i] == current_items[c_i - 1] :
                        # go until you run out of room, or until you run out of matches, or until you run into a problem  
                        while c_i < len(current_items) and current_items[c_i] == current_items[c_i - 1] and current_items[c_i] >= current_amount : 
                            c_i += 1 
                        # if you ran out of room, nothing to do here, break 
                        if c_i >= len(current_items) : 
                            break 
                        elif current_items[c_i] < current_amount :
                            # otherwise, if you ran out items, skip on to the next  
                            c_i += 1 
                            continue  
                    # otherwise, if you have not run out room, and you do have an item worth looking at 
                    # look at it 
                    current_items[c_i] -= current_amount
                    current_customers[customer_index] = 0 
                    # get the key 
                    temp_key = "".join([str(c_it) for c_it in sorted(current_items)]) + "-" + "".join([str(c_c) for c_c in sorted(current_customers)])
                    # check if you have it and it doesn't work 
                    if temp_key in self.memo and self.memo[temp_key] == False :
                        # if it doesn't, unset the looking and then move forward one  
                        current_items[c_i] += current_amount
                        current_customers[customer_index] = current_amount
                        c_i += 1 
                        continue 
                    elif temp_key in self.memo and self.memo[temp_key] == True : 
                        # if you have the key and it worked already, skip out of there after resetting your backtrack key as well 
                        self.memo[backtrack_key] = True
                        return True 
                    elif temp_key not in self.memo : 
                        # otherwise if we have not seen this thing, set up a temp result and lock it in 
                        temp_result = backtrack(current_items, customer_index + 1, current_customers) 
                        self.memo[temp_key] = temp_result 
                        if temp_result == True : 
                            # on success, update and return 
                            self.memo[backtrack_key] = True 
                            return True 
                        else : 
                            # on failure, unset and continue 
                            current_items[c_i] += current_amount 
                            current_customers[customer_index] = current_amount
                            c_i += 1 
                            continue 
                else : 
                    c_i += 1 
                    continue 

            # if you ran out of room or weren't able to make it work -> set False and return it 
            self.memo[backtrack_key] = False
            return False 
        
        # kick it off with our altered nums and quantities 
        return backtrack(nums, 0, quantity)
```

```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums, quantity):
        n, m = len(nums), len(quantity)

        dict1 = collections.Counter(nums)

        quantity.sort(reverse = True)

        def dfs(i):
            if i == m:
                return True 

            for key,val in dict1.items():
                if val >= quantity[i]:
                    dict1[key] -= quantity[i]

                    if dfs(i+1):
                        return True

                    dict1[key] += quantity[i]

            return False 

        return dfs(0)
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
This can be approached as a DFS problem with memoization and greedy search space reduction.

First, one should observe the recursive property of the problem: A customer comes and wants a certain amount of equal integers. There might be mutliple equal integers we could give him, which the changes the equal integers we can give the next customer.

So we need a recursion, that has as input the current customer we are dealing with and which are left and the amount of equal integers we have left. The customers that are left can be coded as a pointer into the customer array. The amount of equal integers ist more difficult. At first, on can realize that we count the amount of equal integers per integer, but it does not really matter which customer gets which integer, it is only important how many we have of those. E.G. if we have four 4's and four 3's our recursive relation does not care or change if we give the customer 4s or 3s. Therefore we can code our state of integers left as a dict, that tells us we have: 3 equal integers two times for the example above.

We can then use these two things (count of equal integers and pointer into the customer array) to make a unique key for a state. Also that state repeats so we can add memoization to not compute problems again. I use a frozenset over the items of our counter dict as a pythonic and fast way to make a hashable tuple from the dict.

The second thing one needs to figure our is that we can decrease our search space much faster by dealing with difficult customers first (the ones wanting a whole lot of equal numbers), as there are only a few possibilities of those, which reduces the number of splits at the beginning of our recursion tree.

The problem really needs some time to figure out. Maybe try to look at my code. I myself was really surpised, I figured this out
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
The approach includes memoization, state coding and search space reduction
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
I haven't figured it out yet, please let me know if you have an idea.
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
I haven't figured it out yet, please let me know if you have an idea.
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:

        # count the amount of same integers
        cn = collections.Counter(collections.Counter(nums).values())
        
        # sort the customers to deal with the most difficult ones first
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)

        # make recursive dfs with memoization
        cache = dict()
        def dfs(items, idx):
            if idx >= len(quantity): return True
            tp_it = frozenset(items.items())
            if (tp_it, idx) not in cache:

                # go though all the frequent items
                result = False
                for qnti, nq in list(items.items()):
                    
                    # check whether we have similar integers
                    if not nq or qnti < quantity[idx]: continue

                    # update our items
                    items[qnti] -= 1
                    items[qnti-quantity[idx]] += 1

                    # recurse deeper
                    if dfs(items, idx+1):
                        result = True
                        break

                    # undo changes to items
                    items[qnti] += 1
                    items[qnti-quantity[idx]] -= 1
                
                # set the cache
                cache[(tp_it, idx)] = result
            return cache[(tp_it, idx)]
        return dfs(cn, 0)
```

```py
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums, quantity):
        """
            observations:
                at most 50 unique values in nums
            
            distribute the asked quantity of nums to query
            
            now for a queery like:
                [1,1,1,1,2,2,2]  q = [1, 4] , we cant take query1 "1" out from  list of 1, bcz if we do, 1 remains = 3 and we wont be able to fulfil 2nd query q2 = "4", 
                
            I think we can be a lil greedy and always give away the lowest fulfilling char so we have 3 "2" and 4 "1" so we fulfil any query less than 3 using 2 
                    
        """
        
        """
        s = SortedList([(c, num) for num, c in Counter(nums).items()])
        s1 = s.copy()
        n = len(s)
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)
        
        
        
        for q in quantity:
            i = s.bisect_left((q, 0))
            if i >= n:
                return False # cant fill this query
            curr_c, curr_elem = s.pop(i)
            if curr_c < q:
                return False # cant fill
            elif curr_c == q:
                # exact match
                s.add((0, curr_elem)) # no more left
            else:
                s.add((curr_c - q, curr_elem))
        
        return True
        """
        """
        ^ code doesnt work for the case
        
        [1,1,2,2,1]
        [2,2,1]
        
        which was actually last test case L.. But idea being the hypothesis that give the lowest count element first doesnt stand true, we need look ahead, i.e DP
        
        bounded sequence donot matter dp ( we need tuple)
        
        dp(?)
        states
        state transition
        base
        """
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)
        counts = Counter(nums)
        
        
        def dp(qi, c):
            
            
            if qi == len(quantity):
                return True
            
            needed_elems = quantity[qi]
            
            for i in c:
                if c[i] >= needed_elems:
                    
                    c[i] -= needed_elems
                    if dp(qi+1, c) == True:
                        return True
                    c[i] += needed_elems
            
            return False
    
        return dp(0, counts)
```

```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], Q: List[int]) -> bool:
        same_items = sorted(Counter(nums).values())
        m, n = len(Q), len(same_items)
        masks = [sum(Q[i] for i in range(m) if mask & 1<<i) for mask in range(1<<m)]  # I call entries of this array "Q_sums"
        valids = set()   # These are the bitmasks that correspond to possible maps same_items[idx] --> Q[i] for all i in mask
        winner = (1<<m) - 1
        for idx in range(n):
            new_valids = set()
            for mask, x in enumerate(masks):
                if same_items[idx] >= x:
                    if mask == winner: return True
                    new_valids.add(mask)
            for x in valids.copy():
                for y in new_valids:
                    if x & y == 0: 
                        merged_mask = x | y
                        if merged_mask == winner: return True
                        valids.add(merged_mask)
            valids.update(new_valids)            
        return False
        # It seems like what I want to check for is if same_items has enough items to distribute across Q
        # So, from indices of same_items, we generate bitmasks saying which objects of Q that we are covering
        # Thus, a valid bitmask for same_items[idx] is one whose Q_sum <= same_items[idx].
        # Further, each entry of Q cannot cannot receive items from different same_items[idx]. Hence, two compatible
        # bitmasks x, y are s.t. x & y == 0. 
        # Therefore, we return true iff we encounter the bitmask (1<<m) - 1 (eg 11111 if m = 5)
        
        # We propagate bitmasks by first finding all valid masks for same_items[0]. Then we find all valid masks for same_items[1].
        # We keep a set of valid masks encountered so far, since it's possible that a valid distribution of items from same_items does 
        # not involve all items in same_items (as the picture I drew illustrates). Then, for same_items[idx] we put valid masks
        # in new_valids, and then for each entry in new_valids, we loop over valids and toss in compatible masks. Continue until see winner or loop ends.
```

```
        winner = (1<<m) - 1

                    new_valids.add(mask)

                for y in new_valids:
                    if x & y == 0: 
                        merged_mask = x | y
                        if merged_mask == winner: return True
                        valids.add(merged_mask)
            valids.update(new_valids)            
        return False
        # It seems like what I want to check for is if same_items has enough items to distribute across Q
        # So, from indices of same_items, we generate bitmasks saying which objects of Q that we are covering
        # Thus, a valid bitmask for same_items[idx] is one whose Q_sum <= same_items[idx].
        # Further, each entry of Q cannot cannot receive items from different same_items[idx]. Hence, two compatible
        # bitmasks x, y are s.t. x & y == 0. 
        # Therefore, we return true iff we encounter the bitmask (1<<m) - 1 (eg 11111 if m = 5)

        # We keep a set of valid masks encountered so far, since it's possible that a valid distribution of items from same_items does 
        # not involve all items in same_items (as the picture I drew illustrates). Then, for same_items[idx] we put valid masks
```

solutions.content:
It doesn't matter what the contents of num are. So tracking the count of each item in nums is sufficient. Going one step further, we can maintain a count of counts and  update the counter while backtracking.

```
from collections import Counter

class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        def backtrack(i, cntr):
            if i == len(quantity):
                return True
            
			# cnt is the number of times some element is occuring in the array.
			# If we use one of those nums, decrement the count of that num count
			# Now the number of elems in the bucket we chose would have decreased and
			# this new count needs to be added to the counter
			# If the number of buckets of  some count becomes zero, remove it from the counter
			# If backtrack returns False, just reverse these operations
			# A temp counter is necessary for these operations because we are changing the size of the original counter
			temp_counter = cntr.copy()
            for cnt in cntr:
                if cnt >= quantity[i]:
                    temp_counter[cnt] -= 1
                    if temp_counter[cnt] == 0:
                        temp_counter.pop(cnt)
                    rem = cnt - quantity[i]
                    temp_counter[rem] += 1
                    
                    if backtrack(i+1, temp_counter):
                        return True
                    
                    temp_counter[rem] -= 1
                    if temp_counter[rem] == 0:
                        temp_counter.pop(rem)
                    temp_counter[cnt] += 1
                    
            return False
        
        count_of_counts = Counter(Counter(nums).values())
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)
        return backtrack(0, count_of_counts)
```

solutions.content:
First, sort the quantity in the descending order, so we always try to serve the largest needs first, then apply as below: 

**The sequence of the principles of being greedy: **

1. for the current largest need, if we find a repeat frequency just equal to this need, then we serve 
2. for the current largest need, if there are any other needs with the same needed amount, then we try to find the largest combinational sum of these needs with the same amount, if there is any repeat frequency matched, then we serve 
3. for the current largest need, find the largest repeat frequency that can satisfy this need, if there is no, then return false. if there is, subtract the need, put the rest back to the repeat frequency pool 

So just iterate over the need values array until the end 


```Scala
  def canDistribute(nums: Array[Int], quantity: Array[Int]): Boolean = {
    val sq = quantity.sortWith(_ >= _)
    import scala.collection.mutable.HashMap
    import java.util.TreeMap
    val stats = new HashMap[Int, Int]()
    val map = new TreeMap[Int, Int]((a: Int, b: Int) => -Integer.compare(a, b))
    nums.foreach(x => stats.put(x, stats.getOrElse(x, 0) + 1))
    stats.values.foreach(x => map.put(x, map.getOrDefault(x, 0) + 1))

    var i = 0
    while (i < sq.length) {
      val v = sq(i)
      if (map.isEmpty) return false
      val maxKey = map.firstKey()
      if (maxKey < v) return false

      var j = i
      while (j < sq.length && v == sq(j)) j += 1
      j -= 1
      while (j >= i) {
        val sum = (j - i + 1) * v
        if (map.containsKey(sum)) {
          map.put(sum, map.get(sum) - 1)
          if (map.get(sum) == 0) map remove sum
          i = j + 1
        } else if (i == j) {
          val remain = maxKey - v
          map.put(maxKey, map.get(maxKey) - 1)
          if (map.get(maxKey) == 0) map remove maxKey
          if (remain != 0) map.put(remain, map.getOrDefault(remain, 0) + 1)
          i += 1
        }
        j -= 1
      }
    }
    true
  }
```

complexity analysis:
* preparing v and f would take O(N)
* max depth of recursion is m
	* for each resurion there is loop O(unique values)
		* for each loop processing cost at max O(3*unique values)
*  Total number of call to recursive funtion m*(unique values)
		
**hence time complexity will be O(N)+(3m(unique values^2))(unique values)m=O(3m^2(unique values^3))**

Im really doubtfull at my complexity analysis will be thankful if u would help me to arrive at correct one if mine is wrong.



```
import bisect

class Solution:
    def toDistribute(self,values,freq,index,quantity):
        if index>=len(quantity):
            return True
        start=bisect.bisect_left(values,quantity[index])
        for i,val in enumerate(values[start:],start):
            if freq[i]==0:
                continue
            try:
                pos=values.index(val-quantity)
                freq[i]-=1
                freq[pos]+=1
                if self.toDistribute(values,freq,index+1,quantity):
                    return True
                freq[i]+=1
                freq[pos]-=1
                
            except:
                pos=bisect.bisect(values,val-quantity[index])
                freq[i]-=1
                temp_v=values[:pos]+[val-quantity[index]]+values[pos:]
                temp_f=freq[:pos]+[1]+freq[pos:]
                if self.toDistribute(temp_v,temp_f,index+1,quantity):
                    return True
                freq[i]+=1
        return False
    

    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        val=collections.Counter(nums).values()
        freq=collections.Counter(val)
        v=list(freq.keys())
        v.sort()
        f=[]
        for val in v:
            f.append(freq[val])
        return self.toDistribute(v,f,0,quantity)
```

solutions.content:
Approach: (click to show) 1. Count how many times each number appears in nums. (this is the frequency of the number) 2. Start at the first customer i = 0 and for all frequencies grater than quantity[0] try using that number to satisfy customer i. 3. When you use frequency[j] to satisfy customer i, subtract quantity[i] from frequency[j] to show quantity[i] of that number was used. 4. Move on to the next customer (i += 1) and repeat the process until all customers are satisfied (True) or no path is found (False).
Optimizations: (click to show) 1. If the frequency of a number exactly matches a value in quantity, use it and remove that value from quantity. i.e. nums = [4, 4, 2, 3] ; quantity = [2, 2] use [4, 4] immediately so nums = [2, 3] and quantity = [2] 2. Sort quantity in reverse order (largest to smallest) so that we address the larger cusomer requests first. This helps identify False answers faster. 3. Do not try to use the same frequency twice when looking at the remaining numbers. used keeps track of the frequencies tired already for quantity[i]. 4. Use a priority queue (heap) so that if a solution exists we will arrive at it sooner and can stop early. This helps identify True answers faster.
```python def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool: # 1. Find the frequency of each number freq = collections.Counter(list(collections.Counter(nums).values())) # 2. If the quantity[i] is in freq, use that number. # i.e. quantity = [2, 2] ; nums = [1, 1, 2, 3] use [1, 1] right away # so we get quantity = [2] and nums = [2, 3] removed = set() for i in range(len(quantity)): if freq[quantity[i]] > 0: freq[quantity[i]] -= 1 removed.add(i) quantity = [quantity[i] for i in range(len(quantity)) if i not in removed] if not quantity: return True freqs = sum(([key]*freq[key] for key in freq), []) # 3. Sort the quantities in reverse order, this helps identify False cases much faster. quantity.sort(reverse = True) # 4. Breadth First Search q = [(0, freqs)] while q: i, freqs = heapq.heappop(q) i = -i if i == len(quantity): return True quant = quantity[i] used = set() # keep track of the freqs[j] values used for quantity[i] for j in range(len(freqs)): if freqs[j] >= quant and freqs[j] not in used: # do not use the same value more than once for quantity[i] used.add(freqs[j]) if freqs[j] > quant: heapq.heappush(q, (-(i+1), freqs[:j] + [freqs[j]-quant] + freqs[j+1:])) else: heapq.heappush(q, (-(i+1), freqs[:j] + freqs[j+1:])) # freqs[j] == quantity[i] we can stop checking other frequencies break return False ```
Here is a more efficient implementation: (click to show) So in the first solution the frequency of each number is stored in a list. i.e. nums = [1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 4, 5, 5] ; freqs = [3, 1, 2, 2] It is more efficient to store freqs as a counter instead. i.e. freqs = {3: 1, 1: 1, 2: 2} Because a counter: 1. uses less space when there are many repeat values 2. can be updated in O(1) time and 3. we can check if quantity[i] is in freqs in O(1) time. However, the python heapq module does not play nice with counters because Counters are not comparable. i.e. is Counter({3:1, 2:3, 1:1}) greater than Counter({2:1, 1:1, 3:3})? Python doesn't know... To use a counter with a heap, we a custom heap class that ignores the Counter part of an item when comparing items in the heap. i.e. item1 = ( 5, Counter({1:1, 2:2}) ) ; item2 = ( 3, Counter({7:1, 1:2}) ). is item1 > item 2? Yes, because 5 > 3 and ignore the Counter.
Solution: (click to show) ```python class Solution: def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool: # 1. Find the frequency of each number freqs = collections.Counter(list(collections.Counter(nums).values())) # 2. If the quantity[i] is in freq, use that number. # i.e. quantity = [2, 2] ; nums = [1, 1, 2, 3] use [1, 1] right away # so we get quantity = [2] and nums = [2, 3] removed = set() for i in range(len(quantity)): if freqs[quantity[i]] > 0: freqs[quantity[i]] -= 1 removed.add(i) quantity = [quantity[i] for i in range(len(quantity)) if i not in removed] if not quantity: return True # 3. Sort the quantities in reverse order, this helps identify False cases much faster. quantity.sort(reverse = True) # 4. Breadth First Search q = Max_Heap([(0, freqs)]) while not q.is_empty(): i, freqs = q.heappop() if i == len(quantity): return True quant = quantity[i] if quant in freqs and freqs[quant] > 0: new_freqs = freqs.copy() new_freqs[quant] -= 1 q.heappush((i+1, new_freqs)) continue for f in freqs: if f > quant and freqs[f] > 0: new_freqs = freqs.copy() new_freqs[f] -= 1 new_freqs[f-quant] += 1 q.heappush((i+1, new_freqs)) return False ```
Custom Max Heap Class: (click to show) ```python class Max_Heap(object): def __init__(self, arr): self.arr = arr if arr else [] def heappush(self, val): self.arr.append(val) i = len(self.arr) - 1 while True: i, b = self.bubble_up(i) if not b: break def heappop(self): if len(self.arr) == 1: return self.arr.pop() res = self.arr[0] self.arr[0] = self.arr.pop() i = 0 while True: i, b = self.bubble_down(i) if not b: break return res def bubble_up(self, i): if not i: return (i, False) j = (i + 1) // 2 if self.arr[j][0] < self.arr[i][0]: self.arr[i], self.arr[j] = self.arr[j], self.arr[i] return (j, True) return (i, False) def bubble_down(self, i): j = (i+1) * 2 if j - 1 >= len(self.arr): return (i, False) if j == len(self.arr): # only consider left branch if self.arr[j-1][0] > self.arr[i][0]: self.arr[i], self.arr[j-1] = self.arr[j-1], self.arr[i] return (j, False) # consider left and right branch j = max((j, j-1), key = lambda x: self.arr[x][0]) if self.arr[j][0] > self.arr[i][0]: self.arr[i], self.arr[j] = self.arr[j], self.arr[i] return (j, True) return (i, False) def is_empty(self): return not bool(self.arr) ```

solutions.content:
since quantity is limited so we can use bitmap to store the status.
we only care fre of numbers in nums, thus we want to get a cnt first.
then we want to allocate each fre to each quantity.
the relation is like a typic dp problem:
dp(i,j)=dp(i-1,j) or dp(i-1,j-s) where i means we have  subarray cnt[0...j],j means we need to satisfy subquantity j. s means one sub-bit of j such that cnt[i] will satisfy s bit-map group=>sums_need(s)<=cnt[i]
eg: the final j is (1<<m)-1) which is like 11111..1111 means we want to satisfy all m numbers in quantity.
thus we want to iterate all sub-bit of j, there is a way to do that descending:sub=(sub-1)&j, which will remove leftmost 1 bit and recover all 1 after removed 1 bit, so we will get highest bit from all remain one.
then we need to compare sums of subset number and cnt[i], we can pre-calcualte it.
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        cnt=sorted(collections.Counter(nums).values(),reverse=True)[:len(quantity)]
        m,n=len(quantity),len(cnt)
        mask_sums=[0]*(1<<m)#pre-calculate sums of need for mask x.
        for bit in range(1,1<<m):
            for i in range(m):#add sums for each bit 1.
                if bit &(1<<i):
                    mask_sums[bit]+=quantity[i]
        
        @lru_cache(None)
        def dp(i,j):#find if exist dp(i-1,j-s) value is True or dp(i,j-s) is True
            if i<0:#no element,only True when no quantity required
                return j==0
            if j==0 or dp(i-1,j):#dp(i,j) is depend on dp(i-1,j) or any(dp(i-1,j-sub) is true)
                return True
            sub=j
            while sub!=0:
                if dp(i-1,j-sub) and cnt[i]>=mask_sums[sub]:
                    return True
                sub=(sub-1)&j   
            return False
        return dp(n-1,(1<<m)-1)
```
